com.rli.util.identityData

Class IdentityPatchOperation

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.rli.util.identityData.IdentityPatchOperation

  • public abstract class IdentityPatchOperation
extends java.lang.Object
    This abstract base class represents a granular operation or change (add value(s), replace value(s), or remove value(s)) on a specific attribute. A patch operation is composed of three main elements:
    • The operation type (add/replace/remove), represented by PatchOpType
    • The set of value(s) for the operation. This can be simple String values or ComplexValue values.
    • The attribute path for the operation, used to represent the target of the operation. This can be a simple attribute, or a specific sub-attribute of a complex value attribute. See IdentityAttributePath for details.

    To get an instance of an IdentityPatchOperation, you should use the following static methods, based on the desired operation type:
    • For adding basic values: add(String, String) and add(String, List)
    • For adding complex values: addComplexValue(String, ComplexValue) and addComplexValues(String, List)
    • For replacing basic values: replace(String, String) and replace(String, List)
    • For replacing complex values: replaceComplexValue(String, ComplexValue) and replaceComplexValues(String, List)
    • For removing basic values: remove(String, String) and remove(String, List)
    • For removing complex values: removeComplexValue(String, ComplexValue) and removeComplexValues(String, List)
    • For removing an entire attribute and all its values: remove(String)

    • Method Detail

      • getOpType

        public abstract PatchOpType getOpType()
        Returns the operation type (add value(s), replace value(s) or delete value(s)) for this patch operation.
        Returns:
        the operation type (add value(s), replace value(s) or delete value(s)) for this patch operation.

      • getAttributePath

        public IdentityAttributePath getAttributePath()
        Returns the attribute path for this patch operation. The attribute path is used to express exactly which attribute (or target for the operation) to add/replace/remove value(s) for. In the case of complex value attributes, it can be used to specify exactly which sub-attribute to change. The attribute path notation follows the SCIM2 specification found here: RFC-7644, page 33-34

        Examples of valid attribute paths:
        • fullName
        • city
        • name.firstName
        • addresses[type eq "home"]
        • addresses[type eq "work"].country
        Returns:
        The attribute path for this patch operation.

      • getFirstValueAsString

        public java.lang.String getFirstValueAsString()
        Returns the first value found in the list of values for this patch operation.
        Returns:

        public void setValuesFromString(java.util.List<java.lang.String> values)

      • getFirstComplexValue

        public ComplexValue getFirstComplexValue()
        Returns the first complex value found in the list of values for this patch operation. Note: if this method is called and the current values for this object are basic String values, the method will throw an IllegalArgumentException. You can call the isValueComplex() method to verify whether this object is using complex values before calling this method to avoid a potential IllegalArgumentException.
        Returns:
        The first complex value found in the list of values for this patch operation.

      • getComplexValues

        public java.util.List<ComplexValue> getComplexValues()
        Returns the list of complex values for this patch operation. Note: if this method is called and the current values for this object are basic String values, the method will throw an IllegalArgumentException. You can call the isValueComplex() method to verify whether this object is using complex values before calling this method to avoid a potential IllegalArgumentException.
        Returns:
        The list of complex values for this patch operation.

      • isValueComplex

        public boolean isValueComplex()
        Indicates whether this patch operation is using complex values.
        Returns:
        true if this patch operation is using complex values, or false otherwise.

        Returns the String representation of this object.

        The String representation of this object.

        A new "replace complex value(s)" patch operation for the specified attribute.
